I'm not familiar with the workings of Buckland's code, so there may be some=
 reason why what you mention won't work there.  However, in general, as lon=
g as your domain is deterministic and your fitness function is static, ther=
e is nothing wrong with only updating the new genomes' fitness values.   Ho=
wever, there are many situations where you would want to reevaluate all gen=
omes during every generation.  This post: http://tech.groups.yahoo.com/grou=
p/neat/message/4956 contains an example of one, basically you should reeval=
uate everyone if there is any chance that you will get a different fitness =
value by doing so.

David D'Ambrosio

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "rvonwah=
lde" <rvonwahlde@...> wrote:
>
> In Bucklands Windows NEAT, the fittest gen=
omes in each species are kept from the previous generation (elitism). These=
 are not mutated.  Therefore, is it correct that there should be no reason =
to update their fitness scores?
> 
> My NEAT application uses the neural ne=
ts in a simulation.  An unmutated neural net will return the same output an=
d therefore fitness each time.
> 
> To save run time, I only update newly m=
utated or crossovered genomes.
>
